Wow... Who knew?  y = - ax^2+bx is the  equation for a parabolla.  I guess it's obvious when you think about it as the minus ax^2 term reaches a max value of 0 when x =0 and equal values when x reaches corresponding  positive and negative integers. The bx term offsets the parabola so that the curve doesn't peak at the origin.

Now just so that my OCD gets some reasonning :
The ball is rotating counterclockwise, moving to the right of the screen, boundary layer drags the air against its mouvement on the bottom and with its mouvement on the top of the ball.
That creates high pressure on the bottom, low pressure on the top : ball is pushed from the bottom and pulled from the top.
You can see it this way too : the arrow wrapping around the top of the ball is correct, it shows the air being send downwards : apply 3rd law of sir Newton my boi and you end up pushing the ball upwards again! :D

A cool fact I learnt just the other day...projectile motion is not actually parabolic. It is approximated to a parabolic path to make calculations easier, but the path is actually elliptical. Or at least, some section of an elliptical path. Just in the same way the moon orbits the earth in an elliptical path, so too do objects thrown in the air!

It's a pet peeve of mine when 2D free fall is introduced as BEING a parabola without mentioning that really it's only just WELL APPROXIMATED by a parabola. I feel like this can cause confusion for students when extending the concepts beyond the typical textbook problems and connecting the dots to other kinds of motion like orbits. The motion is still elliptical in ballistic motion as with orbits, but the distances traveled are short enough that the distance from the Earth to the object remains nearly constant in the problems and the curvature of the earth is also negligible. When the distance is treated as constant and the acceleration of gravity is always parallel to the y-axis, the equation does indeed simplify to a parabola, but this breaks down for significantly large motions. (Even elliptical orbits are still an approximation, but simply acknowledging that a model isn't perfect goes a long way in my book).

I studied bullet ballistics(read: went on a deep dive on Wikipedia) and was shocked to learn that a bullet fired from a gun(without rifling that generates bullet spin) will fall at the same rate as a bullet dropped from your hand.
How could you not know that the Mythbusters performed an experiment proving that a fired bullet and dropped bullet will hit the ground simultaneously?

Without LIFT, gravity doesn't care how fast you are going... it pulls you down at the same rate regardless of your speed. Therefore, if you fired a bullet perfectly level at the exact same time you dropped a bullet from the same height, they would hit the ground at the same time.
Newtonian Relativity!

however, a push in one direction may lead to a counter-push in the other...even if they are ninety degrees apart or other...the net result may be minuscule, but still remains a 'healthy part of the equation'...in terms of solving the mysteries of the universe itself...keep an open mind to the infinite possibilities...Q.

When I was about 13 years old (long time ago now) I programmed a space simulator in BASIC that simulated the gravitational forces affecting masses of different sizes in three dimensional space.  I used this same technique of splitting the velocities into their horizontal, vertical and Z vectors and applying the gravitational force equation to each object, in each of the dimensions.  I didn’t know about calculus then so my calculations were very rough but it worked.  The small objects orbited around the big objects.  Objects closer to each other in mass, orbited around a point between them etc.  Because the forces were inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them, things got crazy when the masses got too close to each other and objects were flung away from each other at massive velocities so I added basic collision detection and if the objects were deemed to have collided, the program made one new mass out of the sum of the two colliding bodies.

The skate boarder in the back of the pick up, is similar to  a scenario I have thought of in the past, where you are standing on the back step of a moving fire truck and you let go of the hand rail just as the truck hits a bump in the road, propelling you upward off the step. I wondered if you would land back on the step, or if the truck would pull away leaving you to land on the road. Obviously from your demo, the motion of the truck is imparted to your body, and you would continue to move forward with the truck, thereby landing on the step. Of course if you bounced high enough, or if the truck suddenly accelerated, that might not be the case. That’s where the math comes in.👌
